Another common failure:
Wrong number of lines expected:<10000> but was:<8913>

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Wrong number of lines expected:<10000> but
was:<8913>
at
org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.LineTrackerTests.testFlood(LineTrackerTests.java:149)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.DebugSuite$1.run(DebugSuite.java:53)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)


This one is probably due to our scheduling rules. We currently enforce that none
of the QueueJob, TrimJob, or MatchJob can run concurrently. We don't however
enforce any ordering. It seems possible that TrimJob could trim part of the
document before it was checked for pattern matches.

Patch seems to resolve the timing issue. It adds the Match Job to a job family based on the console. The TrimJob can then join on that family to ensure that any scheduled matching is done before the trim job is run. This way content is never trimmed before it is matched.
So far, I've had no failures with the patch.
Darin, could you review the patch and try it on your machine?

Created an attachment (id=31771)
cleaned up patch.

This is sort of an API change. We used to use TextConsole.getSchedulingRule() and with patch, we're joining on a job family instead. In fact the getter returns null.
